Research on SCR of NO with CO over the Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O mixed-oxide catalysts: Effect of the grinding Tangkang Liu a Junning Qian a Yanyan Yao a Zhangfu Shi a Liying Han a Caiyuan Liang a Bin Li a Lihui Dong a ⁎ Minguang Fan a Lingling Zhang b a Guangxi Key Laboratory of Petrochemical Resource Processing and Process Intensification Technology, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Guangxi University, Nanning 530004, PR China Guangxi Key Laboratory of Petrochemical Resource Processing and Process Intensification Technology School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Guangxi University Nanning 530004 PR China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lingnan Normal University, Zhanjiang 524048, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lingnan Normal University Zhanjiang 524048 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: 100# Daxue road, Guangxi University, Nanning 530004, Guangxi province, PR China. Graphical abstract The possible mechanism for adsorbed NO reduction by CO over Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O catalysts. In this work, the mixed oxide catalysts Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O with the different grinding time (denoted as x, x=0, 1, 5, 10, 15, or 20) for low-temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with CO are prepared by the grinding method. XRD, SEM, BET, XPS, in situ DRIFTS, H2-TPR, and O2-TPD measurements are used to characterize the catalysts CLC xh, which is objective to illuminate the influence of the grinding on the physicochemical and catalytic properties of CLC xh composite materials and understand the reaction mechanism of the CO-SCR catalytic process. The results show that CLC 10h exhibited the highest catalytic performance, well water-resistance capacity and excellent catalytic stability for NO reduction by CO model reaction, because more catalytic domains (SSOV, Cu-□-Ce (La) species) can generate in the reaction process due to the enhancement of redox behavior with Cu-O-Ce (La) active species, and more active sites are able to form in the grinding process. Undoubtedly, the high concentration of Cu+ is beneficial to NO adsorption and the doping of La enhanced the N2 selectivity of the catalysts significantly. Combined with the in situ DRIFTS results, a possible catalytic reaction mechanism is tentatively proposed to discuss the NO+CO model reaction. Keywords Grinding method CO-SCR In situ DRIFTS Reaction mechanism Cu-□-Ce (La) species 1 Introduction As is known to all, nitrogen oxides (NOx) are as a major air pollutant that are produced by the combustion of fossil fuels, which is the main reason that caused a series of environment problems such as photochemical smog, acid rain, and ozone depletion in recent years [1–5]. Nowadays, catalytic technologies, especially for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology, has been generally regarded as one of the most efficient removal techniques in the field of the NOx removal [2,6,7]. However, the typical commercial SCR catalysts such as V2O5-WO3 (or MoO3)/TiO2 have been widely applied in industry [8,9], they still remain some problems such as high reaction temperature, narrow active temperature window and poor thermal stability. Hence, transition metal oxides catalysts like CeO2, MnOx, CuOx, and LaOx are attempted to replace commercial SCR catalysts for the SCR process. Among them, ceria-based catalysts have been presenting a potential application for NOx removal. It is widely accepted that pure CeO2 has the excellent oxygen storage capacity, transport capability, and redox capability, which contribute to the transformation of surface oxygen species through the Ce4+↔Ce3+ redox process. Moreover, pure CeO2 has been studying extensively for catalytic materials in oxidizing and reducing conditions. On the other hand, CeO2 owns the poor thermal stability and effortless deactivation under the high temperature, and so forth [5,10–12,15]. It is reported that the introduction of some transition metal oxides (such as Cu, La, Mn, Zr, etc.) into cerium oxide can improve some capability of the composite materials effectively, such as redox properties and thermal stability [13–17]. This may impact on the catalytic pathway by changing the physicochemical properties for Ce-based catalytic materials. Based on this purpose, many preparation methods have attracted more and more attention for improving Ce-based catalysts. In the past few decades, many ways can be used as the preparation methods of the catalyst for NO reduction by CO, such as sol-gel method [1,18,19], hydrothermal method [4,14,20], co-precipitation method [3,10,12,16,21]. The research achievements of these preparation methods illustrate that these methods can be used to prepare the catalysts with the excellent SCR performances. Nevertheless, no matter what kind of method is, it always needs larger energy consumption [9] and/or has a certain negative impact on the environment. The synthetic route of the grinding method can be a promising candidate to replace those methods, probably because it owns the lower energy consumption, more convenience for the operation and/or lower influence on the environment for the comprehensive utilization of metal oxides particularly for the low-cost transition metal oxides. Therefore, in this work, a series of multicomponent oxide catalysts CLC xh are prepared by the grinding method, moreover the influence of the grinding on catalytic performances is evaluated from some aspects. In addition, the physical properties, mechanical properties, and other properties of the CLC xh catalysts are characterized by several measurements, such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption/desorption (BET), Scanning electron microscope (SEM), H2-Temperature programmed reduction (TPR), O2-Temperature programmed desorption (TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (In situ DRIFTS). These measurements can provide some favorable information about the interaction among Cu and Ce (La) (Cu-O-Ce (La) species) with the extension of the grinding time and the possible catalytic reaction pathway. For instance, the possible catalytic mechanism are obtained by investigating the in situ DRIFTS results for CO or/and NO adsorption of catalysts. Furthermore, the low-temperature SCR activities of the samples for the reduction of NO with CO are investigated by establishing micro reactor devices with NO+CO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparations A series of Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O mixed oxides are prepared by the grinding method. Firstly, CeO2, CuO, and La2O3 are prepared by thermal decomposition with corresponding nitrate at 450°C for 4h in the flowing air, respectively. And then the CLC catalysts with the same CuO/La2O3/CeO2 mass ratio of 1: 1: 10 are prepared by the grinding method, where the Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O catalysts with the different grinding time are marked as CLC 0h, CLC 1h, CLC 5h, CLC 10h, CLC 15h, and CLC 20h, respectively. For comparison, La0.1Ce0.8O (labeled as LC) and Cu0.1Ce0.8O 5h (marked as CC 5h) samples are also prepared by the same method. 2.2 Samples characterization 2.2.1 BET surface area BET specific surface area and pore structure data are measured by N2 adsorption/desorption at −196°C using a gassorption analyzer (Micrometrics TriStar II 3020 system). Prior to the measurements, about 100mg of the fresh samples are degassed at 90°C for 1h and 300°C for 2h in flowing of high purity nitrogen. BET surface area for each sample is calculated by applying Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. 2.2.2 Scanning electron microscope (SEM) SEM images are measured on a Hitachi SU-8020 scanning electron microscope spectrometer, which can acquire the surface morphologies of CLC xh catalysts. Before the testing, the sample is fixed in a rotating disk with the conductive adhesive. 2.2.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD patterns are recorded on a Japan Rigaku D/MAX-2600 ray diffractometer employing Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15418nm), and the X-ray tube is operated at 40kV and 120mA. The X-ray powder diffractogram is performed at 0.01° intervals and the scanning rate is 8°min−1 for 2θ ranges from 10 to 80°. 2.2.4 H2-TPR H2-TPR experiment is performed on a Pantech instruments company′s Finesorb-3010 chemisorption analyzer using a thermal conductivity detector with H2/Ar mixture (7.03 vol% H2 by volume) as reductant. Approximate 50mg of the fresh samples were treated with high purity nitrogen (50 mLmin−1) at 110°C for 1h at the pretreatment process. Then the temperature cooled down to room temperature in N2 atmosphere, and subsequently N2 (50 mLmin−1) gas was switched into mixed gas (N2 (50 mLmin−1), 7.03% H2 (10 mLmin−1, Ar as balance gas)) and keep time for 0.5h. After that, the reduction process was started with the temperature which was raised from 20 to 800°C and the heating rate was 10°Cmin−1. 2.2.5 O2-TPD O2-TPD experiment also uses the Pantech instruments company′s Finesorb-3010 chemisorption analyzer adopting a thermal conductivity detector to analyze the O2 absorptive capacity of catalysts with pure O2 gas as adsorbent. Approximate 100mg of the samples were treated with He (30mLmin−1) at 200°C for 1h at the pretreatment process. Then the temperature was cooled down to room temperature in He atmosphere, and He (50 mLmin−1) gas was switched into pure oxygen (10mLmin−1) and keep time for 0.5h at room temperature. Subsequently blowing 0.5h in He atmosphere so as to remove oxygen gas in the samples. After that, the desorption process was started with the temperature which was raised from 20 to 800°C and the heating rate was 10°Cmin−1. 2.2.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS spectra is measured on a PHI 5000 Versa Probe X-ray photoelectron spectrometer using Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV) at an accelerating power of 15kW. All the binding energies are calibrated by the carbon deposit C1s peak (284.6eV). Before starting the measurement, all of the samples are pressed into a small and thin slice of the nail. 2.2.7 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectra measurement (In situ DRIFTS) DRIFTS spectra is recorded on a Nicolet iS50 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer, working in the range of wave numbers 4000∼650cm−1 at a resolution of 4cm−1 with accumulation of 32 scans. The samples in powder form are flattened in quarts IR cell, pretreated in the flowing N2 with the temperature from 25 to 350°C at a rate of 5°Cmin−1. After which background spectra (in the flowing N2) are recorded in the range of 350∼25°C at intervals of 25°C, NO gas (5vol% in He, 10 mLmin−1) and/or CO gas (10vol% in He, 10 mLmin−1) is carried out at room temperature. Then the system reaches an adsorption/desorption equilibrium (about 40min), the spectra of adsorbed species on catalysts is collected in the range of 25∼350°C at intervals of 25°C. DRIFTS spectra are obtained by subtraction of the corresponding background reference. 2.3 NO+CO SCR activity measurements The activities of CLC xh catalysts for NO reduction by CO are tested by building a NO+CO micro reactor device, herein the fresh sample (about 50mg) with the particle sizes of 40∼60 meshes is loaded into a quartz tube. The reaction gas is a feed steam with a fixed composition, NO 5 vol%, CO 10 vol% and He as balance gas. The catalysts are pretreated at 110°C for 1h in the flowing N2, and then cooled down to room temperature. Thereafter the micro reaction system are connected to the gas reactants, and the temperature increases from room temperature to 400°C with a space velocity of 24000mL(gH)−1. In the system, analysis of the catalytic products use two thermal conductivity detectors (T=100°C), with two chromatographic columns (Length: 1.75m; Diameter: 3mm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NO+CO SCR activity results The results of NO conversion and N2 selectivity for CO-SCR activity over CLC xh catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 (A) and (B), respectively, with a synthetic reaction gas: 5 vol% NO and 10 vol% CO, and He as balance gas. Obviously, it can be seen from Fig. 1(A) that the CO-SCR activities of the catalysts show a similar growth trend within the higher temperature range (T≥250°C). Nevertheless, their activities display a larger otherness in the lower temperature region (T≤200°C), especially for CLC 10h and CLC 5h samples. It is noteworthy that the CLC 10h samples show the largest NO fractional conversion and obtain approximate 99.2% of NO conversion at 250°C. Interestingly, it can be clearly found that N2 selectivity (seeing from Fig. 1(B)) can appear a turning point, that is quite the minimum value when NO conversion begins to rise effectively. In addition, it is also worth noting from Fig. 1(B) that the CLC 10h sample also has the best N2 selectivity. Besides, compared with the NO conversion and N2 selectivity with CLC 5h and CC 5h, we may reasonably arrive at the conclusion that the doping of La enhances the N2 selectivity of the catalysts observably but results in decreasing the NO conversion. In principle, the doping of La can be conducive to the transformation, i.e., NO→N2, which is critical for the improvement of CO-SCR performance. Fig. 1(C) shows the corresponding CO conversion data, it can be seen that the CO conversion results are similar to that of NO. Moreover, to further help with the investigation of the performance for NO+CO catalytic reaction over the catalysts, the water-resistance experiment are measured. It can be found from Fig. 1(D) that NO conversions and N2 selectivity have become slightly worse in wet condition than that of in anhydrous condition within the reaction temperature range, but the difference is not very great. These results show that CLC 10h sample also exhibit higher catalytic activity in wet condition, that is, the CLC catalysts own well water-resistance capacity. In order to investigate long-term CO-SCR catalytic stability and understand the change of surface active species during the catalytic run, the catalytic stability test for CLC 10h sample in the cycle of 24h are measured (T=200°C), and the corresponding result is shown in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2, we can find that the reaction equilibrium was established between the feed gas and solid catalyst after initial period of 5h, the CLC 10h catalyst show the long-term excellent CO-SCR catalytic stability instead of any deactivation. 3.2 Characterization section 3.2.1 Structural and textural properties The XRD patterns of the as-prepared samples are shown in Fig. 3 . Obviously, for all of the samples, these peaks at 2θ=28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, and 69.7° should belong to the characteristic peaks of the cerianite phase [22], and no other crystalline phases of cerium oxide are detected. This suggests that all of the ceria-based samples calcined at 450°C only appear cerianite phase, in other words, the grinding effect does not change the crystal structure of ceria. For the CLC xh catalysts, only the characteristic peaks of CeO2 and CuO crystalline phases appear. However, none of the characteristic peaks of La2O3 are reflected, proving that lanthana is highly dispersed and/or partially into the crystal lattice of the ceria. In addition, by increasing the grinding time, the intensity of the characteristic peaks of CuO decreases, indicating that the dispersion degree of copper oxide slowly becomes bigger in the grinding process. Furthermore, compared with pure CeO2 and LC 10h samples, the CeO2 diffraction peaks of CLC xh catalysts gradually become weaker and clearly shift towards higher Bragg angles with the increase of the grinding time when the time is less than 10h. This phenomenon indicates that the incorporation of Cu2+ into the crystal lattice of the ceria (the ionic radii of Cu2+ and Ce4+ are 0.072nm and 0.092nm, respectively) resulting in the unit cell shrinkage [23]. When the time is more than 10h, it can be found that the diffraction peaks associated with the cerianite structure shift towards lower Bragg angles and the CuO diffraction peaks begin to increase rather than continue to decrease. This result may prove that La replaces the position of Cu in the CeO2 phase (the ionic radius of La3+ is 0.106nm), causing that the cell size of the sample expands and the CuO crystallite grows. Table 1 shows the crystal size data of the catalysts, the result is in line with the above discussions (the remarkable decrease of the crystal size with increasing the grinding time from 0 to 1h is mainly attributed to the influence of the grinding). These shows that the suitable grinding effect can promote the dispersity of copper oxides on the catalyst surfaces instead of agglomeration. The morphologies of as-synthesized CLC xh catalysts are characterized by SEM. As shown in Fig. 4 , it can be seen that the morphologies of the catalysts are non-uniform nanostructures mainly constituted of agglomerated microparticles, and the particle size of the product gradually diminishes with the increase of the grinding time [24]. The BET specific surface areas of CLC xh samples are listed in Table 1. The BET surface area slowly increases with the grinding time rising from 0 to 10h, but then it decreases when the grinding time more than 10h. This may be caused by the disappearance of the partial pore, which is mainly due to the fact that the sample particles is becoming smaller with the increasing grinding time [25]. This is in good agreement with the SEM results. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution curves of CLC xh catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5 . The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms curves of the product embodies both the IV-type isotherms and a type H3 hysteresis loops, indicating that all of the samples exist a mesoporous structure and each sample forms the pore loop network according to the definition of IUPAC [27,28]. In addition, it is obviously that the adsorption branches of the samples present an ascend trend as the relative pressure increases, especially for the fact that the adsorption branches begin to rise sharply when the relative pressure P/P0 >0.7, which suggests that these samples might have denser network pores structure and a certain number of larger pores [26,29]. The existence of hysteresis loop indicates that these samples are some kinds of porous material with the pronounced capillary condensation effect [20,27]. With the grinding time raising, the adsorptive capacity and hysteresis loop of the catalysts decrease to some extent, which explains that the corresponding pore volume also decreases gradually [27]. The corresponding BJH pore size distribution curves (seeing from Fig. 5(B)) are obtained by BJH method, observing that the BJH pore size of the samples distributes over the mesoporous range (2∼50nm) except the CLC 0h sample. In addition, the pore diameter of the samples decrease when the grinding continues, which may owe to the fact that the catalyst particle sizes gradually diminish and correspondingly cause the disappearance of the sectional mesoporous [30]. 3.2.2 H2-TPR The H2-TPR profiles of the as-prepared samples (as shown in Fig. 6 ) represent two reduction peaks. As illustrated in the recent studies [31,32], the reduction peaks may be classified as follows: the first peak can be marked as the dispersed surface copper oxide, which interacts with the CeO2 or La2O3 and forms the active sites with Cu-O-Ce (La); the second peak at higher temperature should belong to the reduction of the CuO crystalline. Compared with pure CuO, the reduction peaks of CLC xh catalysts shift to the lower temperature range, which is likely due to the fact that the grinding effect results in a better dispersion of CuO [33] and the enhancement of the interaction among Cu and Ce (La). What is more, it can be found that the CLC 10h sample possesses the lowest reduction temperature. Therefore, a suitable grinding time can effectively improve their reducibility (0∼10h), proving that the mixed oxidation interaction (Cu-O-Ce (La)) can be gradually enhanced in the grinding process, which may lead to the great change on the catalysts with related performance in favorable aspects. However, the grinding effect can weaken their reducibility because of the result that the CuO crystalline increases, and the interaction between Cu and Ce (La) becomes weaker over a certain period of time range (10∼20h). These may be attributed to smaller particles size of the samples, which results in the weaker interaction among mixed metal oxides [34]. 3.2.3 O2-TPD analysis The O2-TPD results of CLC xh catalysts are revealed in Fig. 7 . Evidently, the O2-TPD profiles displays three desorption peaks marked as α, β, and δ, respectively (each peak area is shown in Table 1). The assignment of these peaks is as follows: α peak is attributed to the desorption of the surface physically adsorbed oxygen (labeled O2 (ad)), β peak is assigned to the chemically adsorbed species of O2 − (ad) or O− (ad), and δ peak located in the highest desorption temperature refers to the surface lattice oxygen O2− (ad/lattice) [35,36]. It has been reported that the samples possessing more chemically adsorbed species of O2 − (ad) and O− (ad) suggest the existence of more oxygen defect and the better oxygen mobility on their surfaces [37]. Interestingly, it can be seen from Table 1 that the CLC 10h sample has the largest chemical adsorption and maximum O2 adsorption ratio, suggesting that it can have the most oxygen defect and the best oxygen mobility, thereby it probably results in the highest catalytic performance. Otherwise, it can be deemed that the grinding can improve the metal oxidation effect and the amount of the dispersed CuO effectively to a certain extent, which is conducive to improve the redox properties of the catalysts. 3.2.4 XPS analysis The results of XPS analysis are given in Fig. 8 . Most important data retrieved from the XPS spectra are presented in Table 2 , and the corresponding spectra are recorded in Ce3d, La3d, and O1s region. According to the literatures [38–40], Ce3d core-level photoelectron spectra can be divided into eight peaks and they are respectively marked as follows: (i) the six peaks labeled α0:∼915.5eV, α′: ∼906.5eV, α‴: ∼899.5eV, γ0: ∼897.0eV, γ′: ∼887.7eV and γ‴: ∼881.1eV represent the 3d104f0 state that are assigned to Ce4+; (ii) the peaks labeled α″:∼901.4eV and γ″: ∼882.6eV represent the 3d104f1 state that belong to Ce3+. It can be seen from Table 2 that CLC 10h sample exhibits the smallest Ce3+/(Ce4+ +Ce3+) molar ratio and CLC 20h sample exhibits the biggest molar ratio of Ce3+, suggesting that the transformation Ce3+ →Ce4+, i.e., The Cu2+ +Ce3+ →Ce4+ +Cu+ reaction exists when the grinding time is less than 10h, however, it may be a reverse process when the time is more than 10h. These results may be attributed to the gradually enhancing interaction among Cu and Ce (La), besides the Cu-O-Ce (La) active species are formed with the extension of grinding time (t≤10h) [41], which may lead to the results that the samples have more active sites and the transformation between Ce3+ and Ce4+ becomes easier [42]. Seeing from Fig. 8(B), the La3d XPS spectra shows the main peaks at about 850.9eV and 833.9eV, that are affiliated to La3d3/2 and La3d5/2, respectively, proving that the main formation of dispersed lanthanum is La3+ oxidation state in the catalysts [43]. Besides, the binding energy of lanthanum on the catalyst surfaces (∼833.9eV) is lower than the binding energy of pure La2O3 sample (834.9eV), which points out the formation of La-O-Ce (Cu) bonds in the CLC xh catalysts [44]. The O1s core-level spectra are presented in Fig. 8(C). Obviously, the O1s spectra can be divided into two distinct peaks as follows: (i) the peak around 528.3eV is assigned to surface lattice oxygen O2− (labeled as Oα); (ii) the peak around 530.4eV should belong to chemisorbed oxygen species (O2 − or O−, marked as Oβ), it also probably contains surface hydroxyl group and/or carbonate oxygen in the catalysts [39,41]. According to the report [45], the Cu-O-Ce (La) active sites may be generated in the CLC xh catalysts and the surface lattice oxygen species O2 − has the lower binding energy value around 528.3eV (<529.1eV). Furthermore, the CLC 10h sample has the largest Oβ/(Oα + Oβ) molar ratio (seeing Table 2), indicating CLC 10h sample has more oxygen vacancies, which is quite in good agreement with the O2-TPD results. As shown in Table 2, it can be speculated that the grinding effect can effectively promote the formation of more oxygen vacancies and the active sites (Cu-O-Ce (La)) with the raising grinding time when the time is less than 10h, but it gradually decreases when the grinding time continues to grow [46]. Interestingly, the size order of the Oβ/(Oα +Oβ) molar ratio value (seeing Table 2) is well consistent with the excellent order of catalytic activity. 3.2.5 In situ DRIFTS analysis (CO and/or NO adsorption) In order to further investigate the influence of the grinding and understand the reaction mechanism of catalytic reaction, the in situ DRIFTS results of CO and/or NO interaction over the CLC xh catalysts is carried out. The in situ DRIFTS results of CO adsorption on the catalysts are exhibited in Fig. 9 . The band around 2110cm−1 should be attributed to copper carbonyl species (linear Cu+-CO species) and the bands at about 1370 and 1586cm−1 are ascribed to surface carbonate species on the catalysts [47,48]. Linear Cu+-CO species appears for CLC 10h sample at room temperature, indicating the presence of Cu+ for the sample. In addition, for the temperature above 250°C region, the bands that appear at about 2113 and 2173cm−1 are attributed to gaseous CO. Compared with CLC 0h and CLC 20h, it can be seen that the intensity of linear Cu+-CO species is the maximum in CLC 10h, suggesting that it owns the maximum amount of Cu+ species and the appropriate grinding effect can promote the formation of Cu+ species. The intensities of linear Cu+-CO species gradually strengthens as the temperature raises, which is due to the transformation from Cu2+ to Cu+, but then greatly decreases and almost disappears when the temperature continues to grow, as the result, the Cu+ species are reduced to Cu0 species [47,49]. The curves of three representative samples exhibit a similar trend. Furthermore, two peaks at about 2335 and 2358cm−1 are attributed to the formation of CO2 gas. Finally, we can draw a conclusion that the reduction performance with the following order: CLC 10h>CLC 20h>CLC 0h, which is consistent with H2-TPR results. Fig. 10 shows the in situ DRIFTS results of NO adsorption on the catalysts. For CLC 0h sample, as shown in Fig. 10(A), the bands located at about 1228 and 1576cm−1 correspond to chelating bidentate nitrate, the band located at about 1600cm−1 correspond to bridging monodentate nitrate, whereas the bands located at 992 and 1627cm−1 correspond to bridging bidentate nitrate, respectively [48,50,51]. As such, hyponitrites and bridging monodentate nitrites show a band at about 1350cm−1, and linear nitrite shows a band at about 1278cm−1 [50,52]. These similar bands can be observed in CLC 10h and CLC 20h under the experimental condition, as shown in Fig. 10(B) and (C). This peak decreases slowly with the increasing temperature, which is due to the reality that the adsorbed NOx species are unstable and decompose easily when the temperature increases. Interestingly, CLC 0h sample possesses the poorest thermal stability, suggesting the appropriate grinding can promote La and/or Cu ions into ceria phase so as to improve the adsorption thermal stability of NOx on these catalysts. For the phenomenon, Meng et al. [53] presented a possible explanation that La-substituted catalysts own much larger NOx adsorption capacities than La-free mixed oxides. That is, the grinding effect can promote the formation of Cu-O-La species and/or Ce-O-La species. In order to further understand the surface reaction progress of the representative samples, the in situ DRIFTS spectra of NO+CO co-interaction with CLC xh catalysts in the simulated reaction conditions are carried out, the corresponding DRIFTS results are exhibited in Fig. 11 . As previously reported [48,54–56], NO molecules are preferentially adsorbed and NOx species forms on the catalysts surface under the NO+CO atmosphere at the lower temperature. Therefore, the bands at about 1579, 1600, and 1628cm−1 can be marked as chelating bidentate nitrate, bridging monodentate nitrate, and bridging bidentate nitrate, respectively. However, the adsorbed peak of NO molecule is not detected, which is likely due to the interaction between the adsorbed NO and surface oxygen species [56]. Moreover, the peak intensities also weaken as the temperature increases, which is similar with the single NO adsorption results. Furthermore, in combination with the results with N2 selectivity, the reason for the changing for N2 selectivity is that NO molecules are adsorbed on the catalyst surfaces and thus leading to high N2 selectivity for the lower temperature range, then the adsorbed NOx species are thermally decomposed into gaseous N2O with the increasing of temperature, which results in sharp decreasing the N2 selectivity. However, more Cu-□-Ce (La) species are quickly formed as temperatures continues to increase, which play a key in the transformation reaction, i.e., NO→N2, which leading to increasing the N2 selectivity gradually. When the temperature reaches to 200 or 225°C, linear Cu+-CO species show the band at about 2110cm−1 but then weaken until disappear, simultaneously the gaseous CO shows the bands at about 2113 and 2182cm−1, and the peaks increase significantly as the temperature raises. Similar with the CO adsorption results, the bands at about 1368 and 1588cm−1 can be assigned to surface carbonate species for the lower temperature at 200 or 225°C, which possibly means the formation of the evident surface adsorption of CO2 derives from the oxidation of CO and the reduction of the adsorbed NO species on the surface. Simultaneously, it can be seen that the temperature for the appearance of Cu+-CO species and surface carbonate species for CLC 10h sample are obviously lower than CLC 0h and CLC 20h, indicating that the NO+CO model reaction can generate easily on the CLC 10h sample surfaces, which is in good agreement with the catalytic performance testing results. 3.3 NO+CO redox reaction mechanisms Based on the above characterization results, the possible catalytic reaction mechanism for adsorbed NO reduction by CO over CLC xh catalysts is tentatively proposed, the corresponding models are shown in Fig. 12 . The catalytic reaction pathway may include two parts as follows: (i) the adsorption of NO species and the oxidation of CO molecules; (ii) the NO+CO redox reaction. Firstly, NO molecules can be preferentially adsorbed and thus form the NOx species on the catalyst surfaces. Additionally, CO molecules are oxidized by surface oxygen species and form a small quantity of CO2, which results in the formation of oxygen vacancies (OV, □). When the temperature raises, the surface synergistic oxygen vacancies (SSOV) of Cu-□-Ce (La) species are obtained by the reduction of surface Cu-O-Ce (La) species and they may promote a conversion that NO molecules are dissociated into N and O, the N reacts with itself to form N2, moreover the O react with partial CO molecules to generate CO2. Meanwhile, other CO molecules are absorbed on the catalyst surfaces via the form of linear Cu+-CO species. In addition, the partial generated CO2 molecules may be absorbed and form carbonate species on the samples surface, which is reflected in the in situ DRIFTS NO+CO co-adsorption results. 4 Conclusions A series of CLC xh mixed-oxide catalysts with the different grinding time are successfully prepared by the grinding method. Based on the above characterizations, the grinding has a certain effect on the CO-SCR activity and the appropriate grinding will result in the beneficial change of the catalysts properties. The grinding effect effectively enhances the interaction among Cu and Ce (La) (Cu-O-Ce (La) species) and thus leads to increasing amount of the oxygen vacancies, at the same time, the generation and reactivity of adsorbed NOx species are promoted and the redox properties are improved in the process of grinding. Thus, it can be found that CLC 10h sample exhibits the highest NO conversion (99.2%) and the best N2 selectivity (89%) at 250°C as well as well water-resistance capacity and excellent catalytic stability due to the reason that it does exist the strongest interaction among Cu and Ce (La), which may form the active sites of Cu-O-Ce (La) that it is readily reduced to Cu-□-Ce (La) species so as to improve their redox performance, more chemisorbed oxygen, largest surface area, and more oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, the Cu-□-Ce (La) species (SSOV) are identified as the main active phase for NO reduction by CO. The highly reducibility active sites leads to higher CO-SCR performance. Indeed, the doping of La enhances the N2 selectivity of the samples. To conclude, the grinding method may have a potential application to become an environmentally-friendly, fast and energy-efficient method for the synthesis of low-temperature catalysts for NO reduction by CO, also it deserves a deeply potential research value. To some degree, it can provide a new direction and approach for the comprehensive utilization of low-cost metal oxides. coredata.dc:description: In this work, the mixed oxide catalysts Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O with the different grinding time (denoted as x, x=0, 1, 5, 10, 15, or 20) for low-temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with CO are prepared by the grinding method. XRD, SEM, BET, XPS, in situ DRIFTS, H2-TPR, and O2-TPD measurements are used to characterize the catalysts CLC xh, which is objective to illuminate the influence of the grinding on the physicochemical and catalytic properties of CLC xh composite materials and understand the reaction mechanism of the CO-SCR catalytic process. The results show that CLC 10h exhibited the highest catalytic performance, well water-resistance capacity and excellent catalytic stability for NO reduction by CO model reaction, because more catalytic domains (SSOV, Cu-□-Ce (La) species) can generate in the reaction process due to the enhancement of redox behavior with Cu-O-Ce (La) active species, and more active sites are able to form in the grinding process. Undoubtedly, the high concentration of Cu+ is beneficial to NO adsorption and the doping of La enhanced the N2 selectivity of the catalysts significantly. Combined with the in situ DRIFTS results, a possible catalytic reaction mechanism is tentatively proposed to discuss the NO+CO model reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Research on SCR of NO with CO over the Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O mixed-oxide catalysts: Effect of the grinding
